È molto positiva, in questo senso, la decisione dell’Autorità bancaria europea, che ha rinviato al 31 marzo la scadenza sulla moratoria creditizia, accogliendo le richieste pervenute anche da parte italiana. Restiamo, inoltre, profondamente impegnati a promuovere in sede di vigilanza bancaria europea un’attenta valutazione del contesto macroeconomico in cui opererà il settore bancario, per cui si apre - nei prossimi mesi - una delicata partita legata alle modalità di gestione dei futuri crediti deteriorati. Mi avvio a conclusione. Auguro a tutti voi un buon proseguimento dei lavori, nella consapevolezza che i numerosi tavoli di confronto previsti per le giornate di oggi e anche di domani potranno produrre idee preziose per i decisori politici e gli operatori economici. Grazie e buon lavoro
topics_EN: Speech by President Conte at the Rome Investment Forum 2020
speeches_EN:
In last year's edition, we discussed how to rekindle the engine of development in our country, after years of stagnant productivity, wide regional inequalities in employment rates, stagnation in investments due to a regulatory environment that was not favorable enough. In 2020, after the two waves of the pandemic, the challenge we face is no longer just that - albeit a priority - of freeing up the untapped potential of our country. In this new phase, the task that awaits us is twofold and concerns not only Italy but the whole of Europe and, more generally, also the entire international community. First, in the present, we must close ranks to overcome the invisible enemy that is still among us. This is a battle that requires a strong spirit of unity in our communities, a loyal collaboration between all institutional levels of the States, a solid international cooperation, to help each other to reduce the circulation of the virus and to plan an effective distribution of vaccines next year, 2021. In addition to tackling the health challenge, we find ourselves today laying the foundations for a full economic recovery, providing the engine of growth with renewed energy. Undoubtedly, multilateralism and mutual cooperation between countries are essential preconditions for success, because the virus knows no borders or barriers. It is therefore essential to continue promoting exchanges of knowledge, medical innovations, organizational and technical solutions that are made possible only through free trade. The global challenges of the pandemic, of climate change, of a fair, inclusive and sustainable recovery are also the cornerstones of the Italian Presidency of the G20 which has just begun; as well as the revitalization of the multilateral trading system, with the World Trade Organization as its hub. In fact, we believe it is essential that the G20 continue to promote a constructive debate on the reform of the Genevan organization, with the aim of making it more effective and able to face the new challenges of our time. Based on the principles of transparency, non-discrimination and inclusiveness. The spark of future growth will largely be triggered by the need to respond to some basic human needs, health, climate change mitigation, environmental protection, the need for economic and social policies capable of accompanying the technological revolution produced by digitisation, mitigating its transitory negative impacts on employment, guaranteeing competition in the new digital markets and ensuring that new technologies are effectively at the service of citizens and do not exploit their ingenuity and lack of awareness of the risks. For too many years, many of these needs have mostly been considered a burden to bear on development policies. Today, however, research and industry will focus on providing answers to these needs, and the innovations that will follow, aimed at discovering new solutions for fundamental public goods, will be able to constitute the real driving force for growth in the years to come. Certainly, a challenge of these proportions must be faced with the right tools. In this sense, the Italian Government was among the most convinced promoters of the great European turning point that was accomplished in 2020, i.e. the launch of the Next Generation EU project, thanks to which - for the first time - the European Union designs a plan of Community investment, financed by the issuance of genuinely European debt securities and linked to fundamental systemic reforms. Our country must be ready and make the most of this unprecedented opportunity. To do this, the Government's strategy will focus on three fundamental axes: trust, reforms and investments.
To build trust, it is essential to mitigate the effects of uncertainty, which will persist even after the end of the pandemic emergency. For this reason, while preserving debt sustainability, the budgetary tone outlined by the economic package for 2021 will remain highly expansionary, as recommended by the main international institutions, including the OECD and the International Monetary Fund. A faster reduction of the budget deficit, at this stage, would risk jeopardizing the recovery. Furthermore, it is essential to go back to ensuring real social mobility for our country, to prevent the emergence of new and deeper inequalities, and to re-found the relationship between citizens and institutions on new foundations, with particular reference to the tax authorities and the public administration. The tax reform - starting with that of the IRPEF - will have to guarantee greater fairness, transparency and efficiency, helping to reduce the real and perceived inequalities in the treatment of citizens, while eliminating the spaces for unfair competition between businesses. The reform of the PA, guided by its digitization, will aim to make the public administration efficient and at the service of citizens and businesses, investing in its tangible and intangible capital and - above all - in its human capital, something that has been neglected for too long. New skills, new forms of organization, further simplifications in bureaucratic procedures will certainly be needed to fully exploit the benefits of digitization and thus provide the modern and efficient Public Administration with all its info-telematic supports. Of course, the digital revolution will not only affect the country's administrative machinery, but also its industry, schools and hospitals. We can no longer allow Italy to be at the bottom of the European rankings in terms of the digitization of the economy and society, and that our country holds the sad European record for the incidence of so-called "NEET" young people (who are not included in work, study or training courses) out of the total active population. For this reason, the National Recovery and Resilience Plan will serve to strengthen the entire education system, ensuring fast connection in all schools, digitizing school curricula and teacher training, increasing the weight of STEM skills and languages in training courses, giving new impetus to tertiary and professional training,  strengthening the interrelationships between research and production activities with the creation of centers of excellence in various industry segments, which ensure an effective  technology transfer to the entire productive world. And we want to do it, in particular, by ensuring that these benefits fall on the whole country, from north to south, from urban areas to the innermost ones. And we are aware that no growth process can be triggered if we do not carry out a decisive reforming action on the state machine and the legal system. It is for this reason that, in addition to the modernization of the Public Administration that I mentioned, we intend to accelerate the reform of civil justice, to speed up proceedings and ensure more certainty for economic operators. With our Recovery and Resilience Plan we will have to boost dozens of fundamental infrastructural works for the country - such as the sections of the high-speed and high-capacity railway network contained in the "Italia Veloce" project - also resorting to the possibility of additional powers to the implementing subjects, as permitted by the transitional provisions of the decree, later converted, "Simplifications". Finally, public investment will form the cornerstone of our Plan. In line with the strong and innovative direction of the European Commission, we intend to allocate 40% of the entire resources available to our country to a real "green revolution". We want to significantly increase the share of energy produced from renewable sources - solar, wind and bio-methane - so that Italy can successfully achieve the European target of reducing polluting emissions, equal to 55% by 2030, which we just reaffirmed at the last European Council. And this approach is the one that our country wants to share on a wider international level, also in view of the COP26, of which we are partners together with Great Britain.
We also intend to strengthen and extend already tested interventions, but with great potential, I am talking about the 110% building superbonus and the "Transition 4.0" incentive package, which we believe to be a priority, at the same time, to strengthen those investments that have been missing for too many years in the our country, such as those relating to the replacement of the rolling stock of local authorities and the strengthening of the water network and the resilience of forest soils, which is crucial for countering hydrogeological instability. It is undoubtedly a very ambitious and articulated Plan, which in addition to careful planning also requires the most effective implementation possible.
You know, the Government is working to fully define the structure that will be responsible for implementing and monitoring the Plan and which will also be able to make use of an ad hoc regulatory framework to ensure full absorption of the allocated resources, and the grounding of all projects, in the shortest possible time. In no case will this structure be superordinated or superimposed on the necessary institutional steps. Many of the projects contained in the Plan, although supported in the first instance by public resources, will only be fully successful by triggering precious synergies between the public and private sectors, which also decisively pass through the contribution of the banking and financial world. This is a sector that - as unfortunately happens in every episode of crisis - has suffered greatly from the impact of the pandemic. The drop in consumption, in fact, leads to a clear contraction in corporate profits and also affects the profitability of banks. And to mitigate these adverse effects, the Government has extended a wide safety net in favor of the sector through public guarantees throughout 2020 and, thanks to the budget law for 2021, measures to support liquidity, as you know, will also be extended for next year. In this sense, the decision of the European Banking Authority, which postponed the deadline on the credit moratorium to 31 March, accepting the requests also received from the Italian side, is very positive. Furthermore, we remain deeply committed to promoting a careful assessment of the macroeconomic context in which the banking sector will operate within European banking supervision, for which a delicate issue will open up - in the coming months - linked to the methods of managing future non-performing loans. I'm coming to a conclusion. I wish you all a good continuation of the work, in the awareness that the numerous discussion tables scheduled for today and tomorrow will be able to produce valuable ideas for political decision-makers and economic operators. Thanks and good job
